prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of continuum emission, CO outflows, and the structure and kinematics of the gas in the core.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will use one correlator set-up for our one science goal. We will configure one wideband baseband for continuum observations, and three narrowband basebands that will each observe a single spectral line.
Continuum: The continuum band is needed to observe dust emission from the core at 1.3 mm. We will configure a baseband to 1.875 GHz bandwidth to achieve this goal. We are using the wideband setup with 976 kHz (1.3 km/s) channels since there are many molecular lines near ~218 GHz (e.g. methanol and formaldehyde) that may be detectable.
Spectral Line: We will observe 12CO(2-1), C18O(2-1), and N2D+(3-2) in the other three basebands. Based on our CARMA observations of N2H+, HCO+, and HCN, which have velocity resolution ~0.16 km/s, we need to configure each baseband with velocity resolution of at least 0.16 km/s to resolve the gas motions from this young core. To successfully model the centroid velocity and velocity dispersion of the narrowest lines, we will configure the basebands to 61.035 kHz resolution (~0.08 km/s resolution). This gives an expected 3.78 spectral elements per linewidths for our narrowest regions with 0.3 km/s FWHM -- this number will increase for the typical regions with larger linewidth. We expect to smooth the data to ~0.16 km/s to improve S/N in regions with weaker emission, but want to preserve the ~0.08 km/s resolution for regions with narrow linewidths and strong emission.

The target (a dense core) has a maximum size of 40 arcsec in our CARMA N2H+ (J=1-0) observations, so we request a 40 arcsec largest angular scale in these observations. We will observe a 0.833 x 0.833 arcmin rectangle around our core to capture this scale, requiring 17 individual pointing according to the OT. We also need the ACA and TP arrays to complement the 12-m array to recover these scales.
We target 2 arcec angular resolution (~500 AU spatial resolution), which ensures a large sample (~20) of beams across the core and a factor of 4 improvement in the existing observations of dense gas toward this young core, while balancing our need for good brightness temperature sensitivity (see the above sensitivity discussion).
A nearby source at the same northern declination, L1451-mm, has been observed as part of a Cycle 1 proposal with the 12-m, ACA, and TP array. Therefore, although we acknowledge that shadowing will occur for some baselines, we do not expect shadowing or beam shape to be a significant problem for observing this source. Since the target of this proposal is a close neighbor of L1451-mm, and has some similar properties to L1451-mm that prompted this proposal, it means that it is a unique source without a counterpart at lower declination. Similar observations cannot be reasonably acquired at another facility in the north (such as the SMA), because it would take over 30 hours to complete individual parts of this proposal vs. the 51 minutes of ALMA 12-m array time needed to complete all the proposed parts.

The spectral line observations of 12CO(2-1), C18O(2-1), and N2D+(3-2) are the limiting factor for the integration time needed for these observations, and will guide our continuum sensitivity.
1. Spectral Lines:
A. Bandwidth requirement - We need to match the velocity resolution of our CARMA spectral line observations of this region, which were ~0.16 km/s per channel. Our CARMA observations showed that this velocity resolution is needed to properly determine the kinematic motions of gas in cold, dense regions of molecular clouds (see Figure 2 of science justification). Therefore, our target bandwidth for the spectral line observations with ALMA is also 0.16 km/s. Although this gives a linewidth / bandwidth of 300.0 m/s / 160.00 m/s = 1.87, which may seem low, we note that we entered 300.0 m/s as the linewidth because it is the expected linewidth of the most narrow lines from N2D+(3-2) -- typical lines from 12CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1) are expected to be wider than this (> 0.5 km/s width) and provide a ratio > 3 in most regions, and 12CO(2-1) is our highest priority line. Also, note that we will observe with ~0.08 km/s channels and then plan to average up to ~0.16 km/s to reach our required sensitivity estimates. But if we detect strong regions with very narrow linewidths, we can use the 0.08 km/s velocity resolution to better resolve the spectral lines.
B. Requested RMS and resulting S/N - We expect 12CO(2-1), which is our top-priority line, to be the brightest line. N2D+(3-2), which is needed for a lower-priority goal, is expected to be the faintest line. Therefore, we will initially target our needed RMS to our 12CO(2-1) goals, while lowering it slightly if necessary to meet our N2D+(3-2) goal:
12CO(2-1): SMA observations of 12CO(2-1) outflows from L1451-mm peaked around 8 K (Pineda et al. 2011). To be conservative, if outflows from L1451-west are 10x weaker than L1451-mm, with peaks around 0.8 K, then we want to reach a 1-sigma rms of ~0.15 K to have a 5-sigma detection of the outflows.
N2D+(3-2): We expect N2D+(3-2) emission to peak around 0.5 K, based on observations of a sample of very young cores from Hsiesh et al. 2015. To ensure a 5-sigma detection, we push our 1-sigma rms down to 0.1 K, from the 0.15 K discussed above.
Therefore, the target RMS for all lines is 0.1 K in a 0.16 km/s channel, giving an expected S/N of at least 8 for the 12CO(2-1), and about 5 for the N2D+(3-2) line. The C18O(2-1) line is expected to be brighter than the N2D+(3-2) line, giving an expected S/N > 5.
The required integration time to reach 0.1 K rms in a 0.16 km/s channel in a 2'' beam (justification in the next section) is 1.51 minutes, according to the sensitivity calculator. We use this time in the continuum calculations below.
2. Continuum:
With the integration time necessary to reach the desired RMS for our spectral line work, the continuum will reach a 1-sigma RMS of 0.12 mJy/bm. This will ensure a detection of a compact continuum source if it exists; if L1451-west has emission near the predicted upper limit of 11 mJy, then it will be a 90-sigma detection. However, even if L1451-west has emission that is 10x weaker than L1451-mm, it will peak at 2.7 mJy and will be a 22-sigma detection. With this S/N, a non-detection will rule-out the presence of an unresolved FHSC, disk, or YSO in this source.

The data rate is below the maximum, but above twice the expected average rate of 6 MB/s.
We are observing with three narrowbands to detect three molecules from a young, dense core -- all three molecules are important for the science goals. The three narrowbands require high velocity resolution because this a very cold source where observed linewidths have been measured < 0.5 km/s at FWHM in some regions. Therefore, we do not want to spectral average the data. We need to be able to resolve narrow linewidths to be able to successfully model the spectral lines and determine their centroid velocity and velocity dispersion.
We configured our 1.875 GHz wideband using the option that gives velocity resolution ~1.3 km/s. Although this will not resolve spectral lines from the source, it can be useful for detections of molecules such as methanol and formaldehyde, which are often found toward young cores. If we do detect those molecules, we can follow-up with higher velocity resolution observations in a later proposal cycle.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We have discovered a new dense core in the Perseus Molecular Cloud with CARMA. This core, which we call L1451-west, has structure and kinematics that closely match the L1451-mm first hydrostatic core (FHSC) candidate, while appearing to be younger than L1451-mm. These two sources are only 0.8 pc apart in the Perseus L1451 complex. The FHSC stage of star formation is predicted by theoretical models, but has never been definitely observed. There are only a few existing FHSC candidates, so the potential to add another source to list cannot be passed up.
We propose ALMA observations of 1.3 mm continuum to search for compact continuum emission within L1451-west, and of 12CO(2-1) to search for a molecular outflow, both of which will help determine if this is a FHSC candidate, a starless core, or a low-luminosity protostar. We also propose for N2D+(3-2) and C18O(2-1) observations to study the structure and kinematics of cold, dense gas from this source at much higher angular resolution and sensitivity than our previous CARMA observations. These observations only require 0.8 hour of 12-m time, and have the potential to add a new candidate the small list of existing FHSC candidates.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Maryland, University of

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Laboratory for Millimeter-Wave Astronomy, Maryland, University of
